Capacity Building for Small Business and

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  Established in 2003, ShoreCap Exchange Corporation (SCE) is a grant-funded, nonprofit 
corporation that is working to strengthen 10–15 banks and microfinance institutions (MFI) in 
developing countries over 5 years. SCE's overarching goal is to facilitate access to high-quality 
TA at the best value for its clients, primarily micro and small business banks in Asia and Africa. 
Through this regional technical assistance (RETA), the Asian Development Bank (ADB) is 
proposing a contribution of $300,000 to SCE to support its activities. With this contribution to 
SCE, ADB would strengthen its role in contributing to the development of a stronger, healthier 
commercial microfinance industry in its developing member countries (DMC).  
 
II.  ISSUES 
2.  Challenge. Micro and small entrepreneurs sustain and build developing economies 
worldwide, serving as a major source of wealth, income generation, and job creation. These 
entrepreneurs need access to financial services to grow their businesses, as well as accumulate 
savings  and  assets.  Similarly,  poor  households  need  access  to  savings,  insurance,  and 
remittance services to improve their economic resilience and livelihood opportunities. Of the 2.8 
billion poor around the world living on less than $2 a day, however, only 70 million have access 
to credit and financial services.  
 
3.  SCE Approach. SCE, which is sponsored by ShoreBank Corporation, was established 
to help improve access to financial services for these entrepreneurs and households. Its aim is 
to improve livelihoods and increase economic opportunities among these poorer urban and rural 
populations. SCE does this by helping to build stronger MFIs and small business banks focused 
on serving the poor in developing rural and urban economies. Small banks and MFIs often lack 
access to appropriate and affordable expertise and business services, as well as conventional 
sources of capital to finance their growth. SCE helps these banks overcome the substantial 
operational  challenges  they  face  in  dealing  with  poorer,  less  traditional  clients,  and  in 
processing a higher volume of small transactions. SCE focuses on providing assistance to these 
institutions through (i) direct capacity building, and (ii) knowledge exchange.  
 
4.  Capacity Building. In this arena, SCE fields experts to provide targeted assistance to 
its client MFIs and banks in  
 
(i)  microlending and small business underwriting methodologies; 
(ii)  new product development and pricing strategies; 
(iii)  risk management and internal control systems; 
(iv)  business planning and financial projections; 
(v)  deposit mobilization and other funding strategies; 
(vi)  human resources improvement; 
(vii)  board development; and 
(viii)  governance best practices. 
 
5.  Knowledge  Exchange.  In  addition  to  direct  capacity  building  activities,  SCE  has 
incorporated knowledge sharing and peer learning as integral components of its agenda. The 
knowledge exchange program is premised on the belief that entrepreneurs learn best from other 
entrepreneurs,  and  that  MFI  and  small  bank  chief  executive  officers  (CEO)  and  senior 
managers relate well to fellow bankers who have struggled with many of the same challenges

2 
and opportunities that they are facing. In this regard, SCE has engaged in multiple activities, 
including 
 
(i)  launching a CEO exchange forum among its bank partners; 
(ii)  launching a senior manager's forum, which gave bank staff such as human 
resource managers and internal auditors a chance to discuss their challenges 
and successes with peers; 
(iii)  producing a publication that documents lessons and examples of good practice 
among its bank partners; and 
(iv)  holding a 3-day workshop on governance and leadership in Washington, D.C. in 
September 2006 for CEOs and members of their boards of directors. 
 
6.  By design, SCE's clients are locally owned and managed financial institutions. The TA 
methodology is adapted to local circumstances and local financial institutions. The clients play 
an active role in the design of the TA plan through a joint needs assessment conducted with 
SCE. The program is based on demand signals, and SCE's clients pay on a cost-sharing basis 
for services received.  
7.  Projects. In its 4-year history, SCE has been active within ADB’s DMCs and beyond, 
providing a range of TA services to MFIs and small business banks (Table 1). (Details of SCE’s 
activities at MFIs and banks in ADB’s DMCs are in Appendix 2.)

8.  Recent Work. At the end of 2006, SCE had conducted institutional needs assessments 
of five local financial institutions, and had approved four TA plans to serve the capacity building 
needs of its recipients. One of these four financial institutions is a start-up MFI in Gambia 
(Reliance Financial Services); two are small and medium enterprise (SME) banks, one in the 
Philippines (Planters Development Bank) and one in Afghanistan (BRAC Bank Ltd); and the 
other is a small business bank in Cameroon (Union Bank of Cameroon). SCE began executing 
the Reliance Financial Services and UBC TA plans in 2006, and will work more closely with the 
others in 2007. 
 
9.  ADB’s  Participation.  By  contributing  to  SCE,  via  this  RETA,  ADB  will  be  working 
alongside its peer institutions to help build bigger, stronger, healthier commercial MFIs and 
small business banks in its DMCs. This, in turn, will strengthen the commercial micro- and small 
enterprise finance industry, allowing it to grow and provide financial services to more micro and 
small entrepreneurs throughout the region, thus improving their livelihoods. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
10.  Impact. The impact of the RETA will be improvement to the livelihoods of clients (i.e., 
individual borrowers and micro- and small enterprises) of the MFIs that SCE will assist.  
 
11.  Outcome. The outcome of the RETA will be that SCE-affiliated recipient institutions 
become better able to provide sustainable services to individual and micro- and small enterprise 
borrowers. The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 3. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
12.  The RETA will enable ADB to contribute to SCE’s important work in strengthening MFIs 
and  small  business  banks.  ADB’s  contribution  will  benefit  its  DMCs  by  assisting  the 
development of the financial sectors of the countries. The key activities for 2007 will include 
one-on-one consulting for SCE’s clients in ADB’s DMCs, continuing the work mentioned in 
paragraphs  7  and  8,  and  expanding  into  other  areas  of  need  as  determined  by  SCE,  in 
consultation with the clients.   
 
13.  SCE will conduct an on-site visit to understand the needs of each bank or MFI, identify 
potential  TA  deliverables  (e.g.,  improvements  to  internal  audit,  small  business  lending 
methodologies, risk management, etc.), develop a TA plan and budget for the target institution,

training, transfer technical skills, help improve processes and procedures, etc. The key activities

lending methodologies, human resource functions, risk management, and financial systems 
through the introduction of best practices. 
 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
14.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $300,000 on a grant basis for 
Capacity Building for Small Business and Microfinance Banks and hereby reports this action to 
the Board.
